Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Static and Dynamic Magnetization Properties of Spintronic Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early CAREER award proposes theoretical research to investigate the static and dynamic magnetization properties in spin transport electronic (spintronic) devices. Spintronics aims to use the electron spin in addition to its electric charge to develop highly functional and energy efficient devices. In this context a better fundamental understanding of the involved static and dynamic magnetic properties within the confined device setting is of paramount importance for a widespread adoption of spintronic technologies. The complicated interplay of different material parameters and their modifications are essential for the performance of new spintronic devices for their scalability and efficiency. In this project a unique combination of different modeling capabilities will allow a detailed analysis of the functionality of proposed new spintronic devices for energy efficiency in electronics. The main goal of the research project is to enable the theoretical prediction and the computational design of new spintronic materials and devices. In this project the principal investigator will seamlessly integrate educational activities at all levels of education through research experiences for local high school students, undergraduate students and training of graduate students. Based on experience the principal investigator plans to establish "Girls in Physics" events at the University of Alabama with the goal to spark the interest of young female high school students in Alabama in a possible career in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

A theoretical understanding of the static and dynamic magnetization properties for a widespread adoption of spintronic technologies requires basic knowledge of fundamental mechanisms responsible for magnetization relaxation, anisotropy and spin polarization and their interdependencies within a confined device setting. The proposed research plans to combine first principles and tight-binding calculations for material design with dynamical simulations to predict the functionality of new spintronic devices. The unique combination of different modeling capabilities to allow a complete analysis of the functionality of proposed devices will enable the theoretical prediction and the computational design of new spintronic materials and devices. In addition, the proposed research will lead to a better fundamental understanding of the complicated interdependencies of the involved material parameters within a confined device setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER award has advanced our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms and their interdependencies responsible for high spin polarization, low loss mechanisms, and anisotropic effects on the resulting spin dynamics at the device level. This project has provided important new insights into the mechanisms of the creation of large higher order magnetocrystalline anisotropies. Those anisotropies are experimentally observed in many complex ultra-thin multilayer systems which are used in many spintronic devices. Relativistic first principles calculations are not able to account for the magnitude of those anisotropies. By developing an atomistic micromagnetic model, we showed that spatial inhomogeneities at the interface or surface can lead to the observed large higher order anisotropy contributions. Based on large scale micromagnetic simulations we suggested a measurement procedure to confirm the origin of higher order anisotropies due to spatial inhomogeneities. Further we provided a fundamental understanding of the damping mechanism and its consequences for the resulting magnetization dynamics in exchange bias systems. By introducing a damping tensor with a unidirectional and a uniaxial contribution, we were able to provide an understanding of the complex anisotropic damping as observed in exchange bias systems. Those systems are commonly used in spintronic memory applications and hard drive read heads. In addition, we have developed a multi-scale simulation tool to study the thermal stability of spintronic devices. The so called geodesic nudged elastic band method was implemented in our in-house developed hybrid micromagnetic code M3. Quantitative analysis of the annihilation process of quasi-1D and quasi-2D topological protected states have provided important insights for future device designs. So far twenty-nine publications directly related to the project have been published in high-impact journals, with more currently submitted and in preparation. This project has resulted in over forty conference contributions and numerous invited presentations at professional meetings, universities, national laboratories, and industry partner sites.

Three Ph.D. students and eight undergraduate students have been trained as part of this sponsored research project. Eight of those students belong to minority groups in the STEM fields. The outreach program "Girls in Sciences" has been founded as part of this sponsored effort and provides hands-on-activities for female middle and high school students. The developed multiscale simulation tools will continue to provide a wide variety of research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Alabama. Furthermore, the micromagnetic capabilities developed as part of this project will continue to have an impact on the development of new devices for memory applications but also for new computational platforms overcoming the so called Von-Neuman bottleneck, including brain inspired computing schemes to facilitate artificial intelligence applications.
